entry.title: Definition
entry.content: An exponential function is a function of the form $a^x$, where $a\gt 0$ and $a\ne 1$.

entry.title: $x$ is a rational number: $x=p/q$, where $p$ and $q$ are integers and $q\gt 0$
$x$ is an irrational number
entry.content: $\displaystyle a^x=\lim_{r\to x}a^r$, where $r$ is a rational number.

entry.title: Natural exponential function
entry.content: A natural exponential function is an exponential function with base $e$, i.e. $e^x$. $e$ is called the natural base.

entry.title: $e^{rt}$
entry.content:
By definition of $e$, replace $n$ with $n/r$, take both sides to the power $rt$, we obtain:
$\displaystyle e^{rt} = \lim_{n\to \infty}\left(1+\frac{r}{n}\right)^{nt}$

entry.title: Definition
entry.content:
A natural logarithmic function is a logarithmic function with base $e$, i.e. $\ln x=\log_e x$.
Alternatively, a natural logarithmic function can be defined as an integral: $\ln x=\int_1^x \frac{1}{t}\,dt \text{ , where } x\gt 0$

entry.title: Stirling's approximation
entry.content:
Since $\ln(xy)=\ln x+\ln y$, $\ln n!=\ln (1\cdot 2\cdots n)=\sum_{k=1}^n \ln k$ = sum of area of rectangles with height $\ln k$ and width $1$. If $n$ is large, the value closely approximates $\int_1^n \ln x\,dx$.
Hence, for large $n$, $\ln(n!)\approx n\ln n-n$

entry.title: Definition
entry.content:
Suppose $(x,y)$ is any point on a circle of radius $r$, centered at origin, and $\theta$ is its angle measured counterclockwise from positive $x$-axis, then $\sin\theta=\frac{y}{r} \ ,\ \cos\theta=\frac{x}{r} \ ,\ \tan\theta=\frac{y}{x}$ $\csc\theta=\frac{r}{y} \ ,\ \sec\theta=\frac{r}{x} \ ,\ \cot\theta=\frac{x}{y}$ $\theta$ is measured in radian iff arc length $s=r\theta$.
The coordinates $(x,y)$ can then be expressed as $(r\cos\theta,r\sin\theta)$.

entry.title: Addition formulae
entry.content: $ \sin(A+B) = \sin A\cos B + \cos A\sin B \\ \cos(A+B) = \cos A\cos B - \sin A\sin B \\ \tan(A+B) = \frac{\tan A+\tan B}{1-\tan A \tan B} $

entry.title: Subtraction formulae
entry.content: $ \sin(A-B) = \sin A\cos B - \cos A\sin B \\ \cos(A-B) = \cos A\cos B + \sin A\sin B \\ \tan(A-B) = \frac{\tan A-\tan B}{1+\tan A \tan B} $

entry.title: Sum to product formulae
entry.content: $ \sin A + \sin B = 2\sin\left(\frac{A+B}{2}\right)\cos\left(\frac{A-B}{2}\right) \\ \sin A - \sin B = 2\cos\left(\frac{A+B}{2}\right)\sin\left(\frac{A-B}{2}\right) \\ \cos A + \cos B = 2\cos\left(\frac{A+B}{2}\right)\cos\left(\frac{A-B}{2}\right) \\ \cos A - \cos B = -2\sin\left(\frac{A+B}{2}\right)\sin\left(\frac{A-B}{2}\right) $

entry.title: Product to sum formulae
entry.content: $ \sin A\sin B = \frac{1}{2}\,[\cos(A-B)-\cos(A+B)] \\ \cos A\cos B = \frac{1}{2}\,[\cos(A-B)+\cos(A+B)] \\ \sin A\cos B = \frac{1}{2}\,[\sin(A-B)+\sin(A+B)] $

entry.title: Solutions of trigonometric equations
entry.content: $ \sin x = c \Rightarrow x = \begin{cases} \sin^{-1}c + 2k\pi \\ \pi - \sin^{-1}c + 2k\pi \end{cases} \\ \cos x = c \Rightarrow x = \begin{cases} \cos^{-1}c + 2k\pi \\ 2\pi - \cos^{-1}c + 2k\pi \end{cases} \\ \tan x = c \Rightarrow x = \tan^{-1}c + k\pi $

entry.title: Definitions
entry.content: $\displaystyle \sinh x = \frac{e^x-e^{-x}}{2} \qquad \text{domain $\mathbb{R}$, range $\mathbb{R}$} \\ $ $\displaystyle \cosh x = \frac{e^x+e^{-x}}{2} \qquad \text{domain $\mathbb{R}$, range $[1,+\infty)$} \\ $ $\displaystyle \tanh x = \frac{e^x-e^{-x}}{e^x+e^{-x}} \qquad \text{domain $\mathbb{R}$, range $(-1,1)$} $

entry.title: Hyperbolic identities
entry.content: $ \cosh^2 x-\sinh^2 x=1 \\ 1-\tanh^2 x=\text{sech}^2 x \\ \coth^2 x-1=\text{csch}^2 x \\ \sinh 2x=2\sinh x\cosh x \\ \cosh 2x=\cosh^2x+\sinh^2 x $

entry.title: Inverse hyperbolic functions
entry.content: $ \sinh^{-1} x = \ln(x+\sqrt{x^2+1}) \qquad \text{domain $\mathbb{R}$, range $\mathbb{R}$} \\ \cosh^{-1} x = \ln(x+\sqrt{x^2-1}) \qquad \text{domain $[1,+\infty)$, range $[0,+\infty)$} \\ \tanh^{-1} x = \frac{1}{2}\ln\left(\frac{1+x}{1-x}\right) \qquad \text{domain $(-1,1)$, range $\mathbb{R}$} $

entry.title: Standard form
entry.content:
$z=x+iy$
where $(x,y)$ is the point $z$ in Argand diagram.

entry.title: Polar form
entry.content:
$z=r(\cos\theta+i\sin\theta)$
In Argand diagram: $r$ is the distance of the point $z$ from the origin $\theta$ is the angle that the line joining that point and the origin makes with the positive real axis (take counterclockwise as positive angle)

entry.title: Relationship between standard and polar form
Complex conjugate
entry.content: $z^*=x-iy=re^{i(-\theta+2n\pi)}\text{ = reflection of $z$ in the real axis}$

entry.title: Definition
entry.content: Natural logarithm of a complex number is defined as $w=\text{Ln } z$ such that $z=e^w$.

entry.title: Principal value
entry.content: Principal value of $\text{Ln } z=\ln z$ = the value of $\text{Ln }z$ at which $-\pi\lt\arg z\le\pi$.

entry.title: Complex power
entry.content: Complex power $z^w$ is defined by $z^w=e^{w\text{Ln}\,z}$, where $z,w\in\mathbb{C}$.

Relationship between hyperbolic and trigonometric functions
entry.content: $\cosh x = \cos ix \\ i\sinh x = \sin ix \\ \cos x = \cosh ix \\ i\sin x = \sinh ix $
